insights.insight: Ad tech charges $5–$150 CPA for modeled attribution; this protocol settles verified purchase confirmation at roughly $0.10 per receipt — a 50–200x cost delta that isn't a discount, it's a different class of signal.

With Chrome completing cookie deprecation and device fingerprinting under regulatory pressure, the industry has no cross-ecosystem, identity-free, cryptographically verified purchase signal — and receipt-layer data is the only structural candidate to fill that gap.

insights.topic: Receipt as conversion event, not proxy
insights.insight: A DKIM-signed receipt eliminates the attribution problem entirely: no pixel, no lookback window, no modeled conversion — the purchase confirmation is the signal, not an inference about it.

Google sees search intent, Stripe sees transaction amounts, Apple Pay stays walled — no single platform sees verified line-item purchase data across ecosystems; the receipt layer is the one data source that cuts across all of them.

Spend tokens carry no wallet reference, which means no consent flows, no breach liability, and no identity graph to defend under GDPR or CCPA — the privacy architecture is a cost reduction, not a feature trade-off.

21 metro areas reached through burst-quiet-burst expansion consistent with social graph spread rather than paid rollout, with simultaneous rural and urban penetration — the adoption curve suggests pull demand, not push distribution.
